awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track F: Actionable Sensemaking Tools for Curating and Authenticating Information in the Presence of Misinformation during Crises
awd_abstract_narration:
High volume, rapidly changing, diverse information, which often includes misinformation, can easily overwhelm decision makers during a crisis.  Decisions made both during and long after a crisis, affect the trust between responsible decision makers and citizens (many from vulnerable populations), who are impacted by those decisions. This project seeks to help decision makers manage information, promoting reliance on authentic knowledge production processes while also reducing the impact of intentional disinformation and unintended misinformation. The project team will develop a suite of prototype tools that bring timely, high-quality integrated content to bear on decision making and governance, as a routine part of operations, and especially during a crisis. Integrated and authenticated content comprising scientific facts and technical information coupled with citizen and stakeholder viewpoints assure the accuracy of safety decisions and the appropriate prioritization of relief efforts. The project team will synthesize convergent expertise across multiple disciplines; engage and build stakeholder communities through partnerships with government and industry to guide tool development; build a prototype tool for authenticating data and managing misinformation; and validate the tool using real world crisis scenarios.

The project team will create use-inspired personalized AI-driven sensemaking prototype tools for decision-makers to comprehend and authenticate dynamic, uncertain, and often contradictory information to facilitate effective decisions during crises. The tools will focus on curation while accounting for source and explainable content credibility. Guidance from community stakeholders obtained using ethnographic methods will ensure that the resulting tools are practical, timely, and relevant for informed decision making. These tools will capitalize on features of the information environment, human cognitive abilities and limitations, and algorithmic approaches to managing information. In particular, content and network analyses can reveal constellations of sources with a higher probability of producing credible information, while knowledge graphs can help surface and organize important materials being shared while facilitating explainability. The project team will also design and develop a microworld environment to examine and improve tool robustness while simultaneously helping to train decision makers in real-world settings such as school districts and public health settings. This project represents a convergence of disciplines spanning expertise in computer science, social sciences, linguistics, network science, public health, cognitive science, operations, and communication that are necessary to achieve its goals. Partnerships between communities, government industry, and academia will ensure the deliverables are responsive to stakeholder needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

From natural disasters to global pandemics, decision-makers must navigate uncertain, rapidly changing, and often contradictory information flows. Information overload makes the challenge acute. Enter CO:CAST (Crisis Observatory: Credible Actionable Sensemaking Tools), a pioneering system designed to help decision-makers at every level manage and make sense of information during a crisis. CO:CAST is not a fact-checking tool. It is a human-in-the-loop system for organizing information, assessing its credibility, and placing it in context.

 

In Phase I, the CO:CAST team conducted 36 one-on-one interviews, three focus groups (15-20 participants each), and four observations (in emergency response units) that resulted in 216 research interactions with participants. Data was collected in two waves. The first aimed to understand pain points related to how credibility impacts participants' decision-making and their requirements for CO:CAST. The second solicited feedback on the low-fidelity prototypes we had created. Our informants included educational leaders, public health decision-makers (e.g., state-wide, rural, urban, coastal), and emergency response personnel across four states (Ohio, South Carolina, Florida, and Kentucky).  

 

The overriding concern that emerged was that decision-makers are challenged by information overload. Unprecedented access to relevant information, including government agency reports, scientific studies, news, and citizen observations, has the potential to be transformative, but as one informant explained: "We have too much information coming in already, but we need data gathering to help anticipate needs."

 

In a rapidly moving crisis (such as a hurricane), prioritized and credible information is critical as it will critically influence resource prioritization to save lives (highest priority) and money. Our users recognize that every decision they make impacts their trust in the community members they serve. For example, a public health commissioner in a rural county serving an under-represented population bemoaned that distrust of the pandemic response was spilling over and undermining trust in and uptake of unrelated (e.g., maternity) services operated by their department.  

 

Users are clamoring for tools that help them distinguish credible from non-credible information as long as they can flexibly incorporate domain knowledge and user preferences for decision-making. Such tools should organize information into logical groups based on topics, geography, and time, prioritizing data from trusted sources. Users want to understand the provenance of information, including its origins and underlying assumptions, whether from sensors or models. Easy-to-use dashboards that integrate with existing work-practice workflows are also critical. Users also highlighted the necessity for training on these tools, especially in rural areas and understaffed offices that depend on volunteers. Accessible tutorials are crucial to ensure practical usage.  

 

Armed with this information, the CO:CAST team set about creating a demonstration prototype with these goals in mind (building on our low-fidelity prototype and feedback from our users in terms of their pain points and requirements) with the following key features.


1. Synthesizes information from diverse sources: The prototypes can incorporate information from formal and informal sources, including government agencies, news media, social media, and the scientific literature. A specific enhancement over our initial prototype was leveraging large language models to enhance the synthesis of such information while ensuring quality control checks against errors such as hallucinations.

 

2. A Personalized and Configurable Dashboard: One that enables users to monitor crises within and across different geographic areas. It was designed with our users' workflows in mind to include a front-end that seamlessly integrates with various input sources. We utilize an open-source, scalable visualization engine—similar to the ones used by major ride-share companies—to create a front end that supports large-scale geospatial analysis. This system accommodates various human-in-the-loop interactions that are important to our users.

 

3. Credible Content Curation: The focus here is on enhancing real-time information assessment and curation to identify and contextualize information strands. We utilized advances in generative language models to improve topic detection from social media posts. By applying various techniques, we generated plausible explanations for assessing the credibility of multiple sources, emphasizing the need for verifiable, domain-specific details. We also implemented a fine-tuned model using verified information from trusted sources, incorporating retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) modules. Users can personalize the model, share domain knowledge, and correct inaccuracies through human-in-the-loop interactions, helping the model improve future information organization.

 

Broader Impacts

CO:CAST was developed to integrate ideas from cognitive science, communication, computer science, emergency response, psychology, journalism, and public health. The project has enhanced our understanding of its underlying science, with findings submitted or published in leading venues. Our surveyed end users across Ohio, South Carolina, Kentucky, and Florida believe that CO:CAST can significantly improve crisis response, and some utilized the low-fidelity prototype during the pandemic. The project also trained several graduate students, a software engineer, and a postdoctoral associate as part of NSF-required activities during Phase I.  Many students graduated and secured positions at leading firms, while the postdoctoral associate moved to a position at a prominent university.
